I wonder why the game with one of the most caring companies also has one of the worst communities.
Because when you give people freedom and show kindness they will abuse it and the people that play nice get forgotten and overshadowed by those that bend the rules and take advantage.

I would say a very vocal minority can make it seem like the community is awful, but it seems more like a 4 to 1 ratio of decent, even kind people to the one person who's got something they think they have to prove.  Sadly with a ten person game this still means about 2 trolls per game. XD

Any game whether it's pc or console based that puts people on any team to work together to win always has issues because not everyone has the same goal or game experience so you just end up with people getting mad. Examples: Halo, Call of Duty, Battlefield, Dota, League, Etc....

They could be much, much worse. Blizzard is one that comes to mind. Compromising credit card information, banning accounts 6 months after cancellation due to a hacker getting into it, and 'losing' beta key invitations. Trust me, if Riot ends up like that, I'll do the same thing I've done with every blizzard gave I had own; secure erase every game of theirs off my hard drive and burn their CD/DVDs in a fire.

I actually had a really good run in with Blizzard support. I've had nothing but good from them, same with EA oddly enough. Blizzard support literally took my compromised account, and hooked up my brand new account with everything my compromised one had. 

Just shows people have different experiences, and I'm by no means a blizzard or EA uber-fan.
Well that escalated quickly...

People complaining about Rito is good to a certain degree. There is a big difference between talking about Rito's flaws and what it can do better and calling it a "Faggoty, shit-ass company", which it isn't.

I see a lot of people complaining about technical aspects, which is unfair. For example "Fix your servers" which is, to anyone with an ounce of knowledge or care, not that simple. Updating servers is a matter that takes a very long time. They did it a month or so ago in NA, and it caused the client to crash initially. Wouldn't you know, people complained. It bugs me when folks complain about things that Riot can't easily help. There is much better feedback to be made.

The hardest part of coding is by far debugging IMO. The more complex a game gets, the harder it is too fix too. I have played TONS of online games and I have never played one that has been glitch/bug free. It just happens that bugs affect this game more than most since it is so competitive and one thing not working could be the difference between losing and winning.

I think Riot does an exceptional job at keeping the code as bug free as possible. Especially since the game is based on imperfect code.

Complaining, to a certain extent<---, can be beneficial to a company. It shows in which areas the consumers(us) think they are lacking and could improve...though I do understand that there is a RIGHT and WRONG way of complaining

The reason we can say that the systems we looked at have not been exploited is because we weren't running on a version of OpenSSL that was vulnerable to the attack :)
So you're saying you're running a 2+ year old version of it?

Yes, there are reasons one may chose to using an earlier version of a software library. Secondly, some *nix distributions are known to backport the security patches of libraries without pulling the entire patch line, which happened to be our case.  

Though any time there's a known security flaw with a library, we do as every other service provider should and update all affected libraries.


Edit: to reply to Holykow, I didn't say we rolled back. Backporting is a common practice in RHEL *nix distros -https://access.redhat.com/site/security/updates/backporting/
Nothing wrong with that, as this case points out, it lets you avoid popular exploits and afflictions.
